[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Filter bypass] Can an attacker craft transactions that match no rules to always be allowed by default, bypassing all security filters when the rule list is intentionally crafted with non-matching patterns? (Critical)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: allows_transaction()] [Rule ordering vulnerability] Can an attacker exploit the first-match rule evaluation order by crafting transactions that match a permissive 'Allow' rule before hitting restrictive 'Deny' rules, bypassing intended security controls? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: TransactionFilter::new()] [Configuration manipulation] Can malicious validators inject crafted rule vectors during filter initialization to create contradictory or ineffective filtering policies that allow malicious transactions? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: filter_transactions()] [Batch processing DoS] Can an attacker submit a massive batch of transactions that individually pass filters but collectively consume excessive resources during the iterative filtering process, causing validator slowdown? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: is_empty()] [Logic error] Can an attacker exploit the default-allow behavior when the filter is empty to inject malicious transactions during filter initialization or reset states? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: add_multiple_matchers_filter()] [Rule injection] Can an attacker exploit race conditions during dynamic filter updates to inject 'Allow' rules for malicious addresses or functions while filters are being modified? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Struct: TransactionFilter] [Serialization attack] Can an attacker craft malicious serialized filter configurations that, when deserialized, create filters with unintended behavior or bypass security checks? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: TransactionMatcher::matches()] [Pattern matching bypass] Can an attacker exploit the All matcher to create overly permissive filters that accidentally allow all transactions including malicious ones? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches()] [Transaction ID collision] Can an attacker craft transactions with committed_hash collisions to bypass TransactionId matchers and evade transaction-specific filtering rules? (Critical)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_sender_address()] [Sender spoofing] Does the sender address matching properly validate transaction signatures, or can an attacker forge sender addresses to bypass Sender matchers? (Critical)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function_module_address()] [Module address confusion] Can an attacker deploy malicious contracts at addresses that match legitimate module addresses in filter rules, bypassing security controls? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_entry_function()] [Function name collision] Can an attacker create entry functions with identical (address, module, function) tuples to legitimate functions to bypass entry function filters? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches()] [AccountAddress matcher abuse] Does the AccountAddress matcher check ALL possible locations where an address appears, or can an attacker hide malicious addresses in unchecked transaction fields? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches()] [PublicKey matcher bypass] Can an attacker use alternative authentication schemes (Abstract, NoAccountAuthenticator) to bypass public key matchers entirely? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [Ed25519 bypass] Can an attacker exploit the fact that Ed25519 and MultiEd25519 authenticators return false for address matching to hide malicious signers? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [SingleKey address extraction] Does the SingleKey authenticator properly validate that extracted addresses from public keys match expected values, or can forged public keys bypass checks? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [MultiKey enumeration attack] Can an attacker exploit the any() iterator to cause excessive CPU usage by including thousands of public keys in MultiKey authenticators? (Low)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_address()] [Abstract authenticator module address confusion] Can an attacker register malicious abstract authenticator modules at filtered addresses to gain unauthorized access? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [NoAccountAuthenticator bypass] Can transactions with NoAccountAuthenticator skip all public key validation and bypass filters entirely? (Critical)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [Abstract authenticator public key bypass] Can abstract authenticators completely bypass public key filtering since they return false for all public key matches? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: compare_ed25519_public_key()] [Key type confusion] Can an attacker bypass Ed25519 public key filters by using other key types (Secp256k1, Secp256r1, Keyless) that will never match? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_account_authenticator_public_key()] [MultiEd25519 partial match] Does the any() check in MultiEd25519 allow transactions where only ONE key matches the filter, even if other keys are malicious? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [Keyless key bypass] Can attackers using Ed25519, Secp256k1, Secp256r1, or regular Keyless keys completely bypass address-based filters since they return false? (Medium)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [FederatedKeyless JWK address spoofing] Can an attacker manipulate the jwk_addr field in FederatedKeyless public keys to match filtered addresses and gain unauthorized access? (High)

[File: crates/aptos-transaction-filters/src/transaction_filter.rs] [Function: matches_any_public_key_address()] [Future key type vulnerability] Are all current and future AnyPublicKey variants explicitly handled, or could new key types bypass address filtering due to incomplete pattern matching? (Medium)
